data.content: First, go to  Control Panel. Next, in View by**  select **Large icons** (1) then select **“Programs and Features”** (2)
Then,click on Turn Windows features on or off

You must first install the optional feature Windows Subsystem for Linux and Virtual Machine Platform before installing Linux  on Windows.


First  go to Control Pane / Programs and Feature / Turn Windows features on or off. Then, select the available Virtual Machine Platform (1) and Windows Subsystem for Linux  (2) options and click on “OK”.
When the installation has finished, you will see the message Windows completed the requested changes. Then, click on Restart now
At this point a window will appear showing the Windows features that you can turn on or off. Select the available Hyper-V options and click on “OK”.
Download linux kernel update package, you can be found download the linux kernel update package .
To enable WSL 2 by default, go to open Windows PowerShell  execute as administrator and run this command.
Open the application Microsoft Store and select linux distribution.

The latest Windows binary of the Docker Destop Installer is available for download on Docker.com


Detailed steps are presented in the official documentation on Docker.com : Install docker desktop on Windows

# Add Docker's official GPG key:

sudo apt-get update

sudo apt-get install ca-certificates curl

sudo install -m 0755 -d /etc/apt/keyrings

sudo curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg -o /etc/apt/keyrings/docker.asc

sudo chmod a+r /etc/apt/keyrings/docker.asc


# Add the repository to Apt sources:

echo \

  "deb [arch=$(dpkg --print-architecture) signed-by=/etc/apt/keyrings/docker.asc] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu \

  $(. /etc/os-release && echo "$VERSION_CODENAME") stable" | \

  sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/docker.list > /dev/null

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io docker-buildx-plugin docker-compose-plugin
sudo dnf install docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io docker-buildx-plugin docker-compose-plugin
sudo yum install docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io docker-buildx-plugin docker-compose-plugin
Download the Docker Compose file from github
Open the application Docker Desktop, then click on Containers you can see your container dockerequals is running

Remember to map the default domain name with an IP address in your local hosts file :


  • Windows : `C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts`
You can now either browse to the welcome screen: http://equal.local
Or start a shell on the container :

Method 1:


eQual expects an optional root config file in the `/config` directory.


To go on the /config directory:


  1. Open your folder on Visual Studio Code with Docker Desktop.
  2. Go first on  /www/html directory then in the /config directory.
  3. To create and customize your config file, start by creating `config.json`:

Method 2:﻿


To create and customize your config file, start by creating `config.json`:
To write to your config file, type the following comand
As an alternative, you can also use one of the example config files, by copying
Here is a minimalist `config.json` that you can adapt according to your environment:

Method 3:


Generate the config file with the generate controller :
You should now have a properly configured environment and be able to perform some operations calls.
To make sure the DBMS can be access, you can use the following controller :

Upon success this controller exits with no message (exit 0), and the database is created. If an error occurs, a JSON message is returned with a short description about the issue.


Example:

{

    "errors": {

        "INVALID_CONFIG": "Unable to establish connection to DBMS host

        (wrong hostname or port)"

    }

}

The database can be created by using the `core_init_db controller`.


  • PATH : `core\actions\init\db.php`
  • URL : `?do=init_db`
  • CLI : `$ ./equal.run --do=init_db`
  • DESCRIPTION : Creates a database using the details provided in config file. This controllers calls db-connectivity and if connection can be established with the host, it requests the creation of the database, if it does not exist yet.

In order to be able to manipulate entities, the related package needs to be initialized (each package contains the class definition of its own entities). This can be done by using the `core_init_package` controller.


  • PATH : `core\actions\init\package.php`
  • URL : `?do=init_package&package=core`
  • CLI : `$ ./equal.run --do=init_package --package=core --import=true`
  • DESCRIPTION : Initialize database for given package. If no package is given, initialize core package.


Now, you should be able to fetch data by using the controllers from the `core` package.


Example:


PATH : `core\data\model\collect.php`

URL : `?get=model_collect&entity=core\User`

CLI : `$ ./equal.run --get=model_collect --entity=core\\User`

DESCRIPTION : Returns a list of entites according to given domain (filter), start offset, limit and order.

A list of routes related to default API is defined in `/config/routing/99-default.json`. Here below are some examples of HTTP calls and their responses (in JSON) that you can us to test your installation:
Fetch the details of the root user
Fetch the full list of existing users
Fetch the full list of existing groups
Note: The body request may be empty, but it is preferable to specify a name for a group.

id field


All entities are identified with an id, which is an auto increment field and is generated automatically.
Update the 'name' property of the group
